Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I walked through the door, still thinking about the petition deadline. My phone buzzed with reminders from the activist group—this was the last chance to add my name before the letter went to the lawmaker. As I set my bag down, my partner greeted me with a tired smile and mentioned, almost offhand, that work had been rough. I could see the tension in their shoulders, the way they lingered in the kitchen, hoping I’d ask for details or offer comfort. I wanted to be present, to listen, to give them the support they deserved after a long day. But my mind kept drifting to the petition, the cause I’d spent months fighting for, and the pressure from my fellow activists who were counting on every signature. I felt torn, standing in the hallway, phone in hand, heart pulled in two directions—toward the person I love and the cause I believe in.
